security_audit.summary: This skill provides spreadsheet processing capabilities using openpyxl and pandas libraries. The included recalc.py script executes LibreOffice soffice command for formula recalculation, which is necessary and documented functionality. All filesystem access is limited to the specified Excel file and LibreOffice user config directory.

low_findings.title: External command execution for LibreOffice
low_findings.description: The recalc.py script executes LibreOffice soffice command to recalculate Excel formulas. This is legitimate functionality required because openpyxl does not evaluate formulas. The script uses hardcoded commands: 'soffice --headless --norestore' and optionally 'timeout'/'gtimeout' for process control. An attacker could potentially manipulate the input filename to access unauthorized files, though this is limited by the subprocess call structure.

low_findings.title: User config directory filesystem access
low_findings.description: The script creates and writes to LibreOffice configuration directory in user home: ~/.config/libreoffice/ (Linux) or ~/Library/Application Support/LibreOffice/ (macOS). This is necessary for macro setup but involves writing to user config space.

content.value_statement: This skill provides tools for creating, editing, and analyzing Excel spreadsheets. It handles formulas, formatting, data analysis, and formula recalculation using LibreOffice. Perfect for financial modeling, data processing, and spreadsheet automation tasks.
actual_capabilities: Create Excel workbooks with openpyxl including formulas and formatting
Edit existing Excel files while preserving formulas and styles
Analyze data using pandas for reading, processing, and exporting
Recalculate Excel formulas using LibreOffice headless mode
Detect and report formula errors like #REF!, #DIV/0!, #VALUE!
Apply financial model standards with color coding and formatting
limitations: Formula recalculation requires LibreOffice installed on the system
openpyxl does not evaluate formulas - recalc.py script handles this
Large files may require read_only or write_only mode for performance

use_cases.title: Data analysis and reporting
use_cases.description: Process and analyze Excel data, create summary reports, and export results to spreadsheet format.

use_cases.title: Financial modeling
use_cases.description: Build financial models with formulas, color coding standards, and proper formatting conventions.

use_cases.title: Spreadsheet automation
use_cases.description: Automate spreadsheet creation and updates, apply formatting, and recalculate complex formulas.

prompt_templates.title: Create simple spreadsheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Excel file named output.xlsx with columns A-E and 10 rows of sample sales data. Add a SUM formula in row 11 and format the header row with bold text.

prompt_templates.title: Edit existing file
prompt_templates.prompt: Load existing.xlsx, add a new column F with a formula that calculates percentage growth. Apply number formatting and save the file.

prompt_templates.title: Financial model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 5-year financial projection model with assumptions in separate cells. Use blue for inputs, black for formulas, and green for cross-sheet references. Apply currency formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Formula verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complex spreadsheet with formulas, then run recalc.py to verify all formulas calculate correctly. Report any errors found and their locations.

output_examples.input: Create a budget spreadsheet with monthly expenses for Q1. Include categories for rent, utilities, salaries, and supplies. Add formulas for totals and percentages.
output: Created budget.xlsx with 4 sheets (Summary, January, February, March)
Added assumptions section for monthly amounts
Formulas: =SUM(B2:B5) for category totals, =SUM(B2:F5) for grand total
Formatting: Blue text for input cells, black for formulas
Run 'python recalc.py budget.xlsx' to recalculate all formulas

best_practices: Always use Excel formulas instead of hardcoded values so the spreadsheet remains dynamic
Place assumptions in separate cells with clear references rather than magic numbers
Run recalc.py after creating or modifying files with formulas to verify zero errors
Test formulas on a few cells before applying to the entire spreadsheet
anti_patterns: Calculating values in Python and hardcoding them in Excel instead of using formulas
Opening files with data_only=True and saving, which permanently removes formulas
Ignoring Excel error messages like #REF! or #DIV/0! without fixing them
Using cell references without verifying they point to the intended cells

faq.question: Which library should I use for my task?
faq.answer: Use pandas for data analysis and bulk operations. Use openpyxl for formulas, formatting, and Excel-specific features.

faq.question: Why do formulas show as strings after creating files?
faq.answer: openpyxl preserves formulas but does not evaluate them. Run recalc.py to calculate all formula values.

faq.question: Can I read calculated values from existing files?
faq.answer: Yes, use load_workbook('file.xlsx', data_only=True). Warning: saving with this mode removes formulas.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using recalc.py?
faq.answer: The script only reads and writes the specified Excel file. It creates a LibreOffice macro in user config for recalculation.

faq.question: What if LibreOffice is not installed?
faq.answer: Formula recalculation requires LibreOffice. Install via package manager (apt, brew) or download from libreoffice.org.

faq.question: How is this different from pandas Excel handling?
faq.answer: pandas reads data values only. openpyxl preserves formulas, formatting, and styles. Use both together for complete spreadsheet handling.
